@BoostVC is the accelerator for Sci-Fi Tech. We invest $500k for 15% of a company. 

Applications are open: https://t.co/FGfTCngycp
Demo Day for investors is Tuesday: https://t.co/Srr2d211Sc

10/ My team has made every pitfall we have faced worth it. Thanks @BraytonKey @MaddieCallander Langa and Jess!

Whether a VC or a founder... only surround yourself with the best.

Also shout out to my #1 cheerleader, my wife!
9/ The magic of early stage is the human connection. The potential impact that could be made. And the fun of not knowing all the answers.

8/ At the earliest stages of a startup, it is impossible to know what will work as an investor:

The common thread with successful founders I know has been:

üôáThe desire to win (COMPETITIVE)
‚úçÔ∏èIterative habit of bettering themselves
üòÄAlso they have been extremely likable

7/ Networks are compounding

In venture, creating branded network that is the difference between Alumni and Portfolio is a moat! Those people involved define your brand.

üöÄAuthenticity and time builds a brand

YOUR BRAND AND NETWORK ARE PARAMOUNT.

6/ Every early stage startup has similar stages:

üí°Ideation
üíªCreation
üìàDistribution
‚è±Ô∏èRegulation

Depending on what stage you are at, success is generally determined by lowering the cost associated with of each of these elements.

VCs can be helpful in reducing those costs
5/ The difference between an angel investor and a fund manager is that a deal that does 3x doesn't return a fund, but an angel is stoked!

4/ The world is moving from individuals who are good at the "art" of venture to the scale of "Venture Science" and in that, the models that will define the venture capital market in the future are @cartainc @AngelList @ycombinator ... and obviously @BoostVC

3/ VCs can only really offer 3 things
üí∏Money
üë®‚ÄçüíºExperience
üï∏Ô∏èNetwork

But all of these things, depending on who is delivering, can be asymmetrically helpful or harmful

2/ VC is a business too, and it's being disrupted:
üôè Building trust online gives accelerated investment timeline
ü§ùAccess online gives accelerated networking, no more proprietary deal flow
üéôÔ∏èWe are all either media companies backed by assets or asset companies supported by media

I want to see that for our generation.
7/ In 1957, Russia launched Sputnik, within 12 years, America landed on the moon.\n\nWhen governments and humans are singularly focused on one outcome, it happens.

6/ JFK had his famous space speech, "We choose to go to the Moon in this decade and do the other things, not because they are easy, but because they are hard; because that goal will serve to organize and measure the best of our energies and skills"\nhttps://t.co/rur4xSPA25

5/ For Space, the journey started for the United states with the uncertainty of Sputnik circling earths orbit above the United States. \n\nRussia had done something so innovative during the Cold War, that it spread fear, and accelerated rocket science over the next 10 years
4/ We remember the Wright brothers because they succeeded.\n\nA couple of bicycle engineers in Dayton Ohio decided it was possible to fly, and so they did.

3/ Samuel Pierpont Langley was a well known aeronautical engineer of the time, who had successfully launched an unmanned aircraft 10 times farther than anyone previously. Which gained him notoriety, however manned air still evaded him. He was also the most well financed.

2/ Both of these events were spurred by competition:

Otto Lilienthal was a German engineer who repeated flew gliders, which was also what killed him.

His research inspired many to attempt to successfully build a piloted heavier than air, aircraft.

1/ In 1903, the Wright brothers officially flew the first manned aircraft.

In 1969, the United States flew a manned spacecraft to the moon.

That means in less than a life time, humanity went from:

üö´"People can't fly!"

to

üåù"We are on the moon"

Renegades: Similar to Amazon's "The boys", in general concept. But I love that the author jumpstarted a whole world and characters for superheroes through a novel rather than comic series. I think that this will have a huge following (there are two other books)

Best Sci-Fi/Fantasy: It gives you a snap shot of how Sci-Fi and fantasy are being pictured at a given moment. And some of the writing is just beautiful.\n\nSex/Drugs/Cocoa Puffs: If you ever want to see brilliant perspectives that you won't agree with always, read Klosterman.

Why I liked them:

Recursion: Created a world where it felt possible to time-travel, it's a fast read and your imagination runs wild with the possibilities.

Dark Matter: The concept of the multi-verse and how it could fundamentally work shifts your perspective on decisions.
Just another #VC sharing what he read.

9/ If someone has chosen to pursue a life long mission, we want to be the one to enable their pursuit. \n\nSo many people will say "it's not possible." We like to say, "What if it works."
8/ We are obsessed with what we do.
7/ I'm a firm believer that surrounding yourself with an electric network gives you better chance of success as a startup, we curate the correct people to surround your startup with.

6/ We have a concierge approach to the accelerator, focused on providing 1v1 interactions with all startups, if you go through the program, you work with me, @BraytonKey and @MaddieCallander - we don't hand off.
5/ We are the accelerator that invests the most money, $500k is a lot of money.
5/ We provide housing and office space in the center of Silicon Valley for our 3 month accelerator program.
4/ We have invested in @takeonGravity and @JetPackAviation ... which means we have a monopoly on all jetpack startups. And that we take risk on things people believe to be impossibilities.
3/ We were the first accelerator or investment entity for #Bitcoin startups. Same with #VR.

2/ We have invested in 100 Crypto startups, 80 VR startups and 270+ startups total. We support ecosystems through the hard times and the good. We support industries before anyone else knows they exist.

@arrington @TimDraper Love your optimism about this. I love hearing stories from my Dad's history, so thanks for that.
@DittmerChase I guess its a risk adjusted return. I just always want to keep people questioning the assumptions we make in making decisions.

@kyunbit Its what the market rate is for venture capitalists. I think it's a fair assessment of "Can the person get customers". I'm not saying that startups shouldnt continue to use the metric to fundraise, I just think that we will see an evolution of this metric.

@mcarney What spurred the tweet: An observation on the entire market. My job is to see where people are over-valuing things in industries, people are over-valuing ARR believing it to be a fundamental truth.\n\nWeWork: The tweet had nothing to do with WeWork, but it does apply.

@carlosaddsub @mcarney and we as investors want to bucket everything into categories. I understand why the ARR metric has risen to prominence, I think the way people use it is fascinating... and often an incorrect assumption.

@mcarney You would be credit scoring customers over a specific time frame with the belief that past dictates future returns. That habit and assumption compounded and stacked over an entire industry is scary... I live in early stage, how much of a customer base do you make a decision on

@mcarney Assuming someone is going to continue to purchase a product over a 12 month time frame is what everyone is fundraising on. Because someone has bought it one month does not dictate future purchase.
I think ARR may be the biggest lie accepted by the whole #VC industry. \n\nBut I keep finding myself buying into it.

7/ Investors will have tried #VR. This will create more velocity of capital into the technology!
6/ You can now explain what you do at every meeting you are in, by building a product, and putting the device on someones head. This will lead to increased understanding of the opportunities in VR.

5/ Collecting information to contact users becomes more important. Up until now, everyone has used Discord for their communities, but the average user doesn't use @discordapp yet. How do we remind users to come back?
4/ Analytics become more important. Up until now, we have only had early adopters on the platform, now we get to know the average consumer better.
3/ But for entrepreneurs, there are a few other interesting things that change.

2/ The obvious thing is that we will start to see VR in the wild.\n\nOne of our friends will have it. And it spreads like wild fire. It's the most viral product I've ever seen. (Yes, I have sold like 20 just by letting friends try it)

11/ Thank you to the builders. \n\nGood technology can often look like magic, and #VR blows my mind.
10/ This ecosystem was built on the hope and promise of a better product, and I believe that @oculus delivered it.
9/ @oculus Oculus launched the first consumer ready #VR device. This device is going to change society. I'm very proud to be a part of this ecosystem.
8/ The Oculus Quest was not built by one person, it was built by the whole community, which is what makes it special.

7/ There aren‚Äôt many moments in technology history that you can point at and say ‚ÄúThat was it, that was the product that changed the industry.‚Äù I would argue that the past few were the Macintosh and the iPhone for consumer products, today it is the @oculus Quest.
6/ @BoostVC is lucky to have supported 70+ startups in this ecosystem for a long time. And we rejoice today... with the launch of the #quest.
5/ Yet still over years, they believed in the future product and the promise of connectivity it would bring.
4/ They had to be questioned by people who had not tried #VR, about the feasibility of the industry and the business.
3/ They had to sell a vision of their product, being built on a technology that was still unproven.
2/ They had to lug 20 pounds of equipment to pitch meetings, unpack the computer, the sensors and the headset, set it up and then ask people to put a vizor on their heads.
1/ For the last 5 years, the #VR builders and entrepreneurs have had to beg people to try their experiences.

17. Startups that do not solve a problem, but are a cool piece of technology. They die.
16. Founders that give blame to their team for mistakes rather than take it on themselves. The startup dies.
15. Founders who do not ask for help. They die.
14. Founders who "want to start a startup." They die. Sometimes they learn on the second one that it's about solving a problem.
13. A consensus driven founder doesn't make decisions fast enough, or have confidence in themselves or their decision making. They die.
12. A founder who stares at what the competition does at the earliest stages, doesn't understand that the only competition is yourself. They die.
Continued after lunch\n11. A founder who thinks their investors are their customers, they don't have conviction. They die.
10. There are more. But I have to get to a lunch meeting. So if you have more, please add them here.
9. Pessimists can't create a movement. They die.
8. Startup founders that think that Venture Capitalists are validators of their success. They die.
7. A company that does not talk to their customer, and believe they have a sharper stick... they die. Pick up the phone and call customers.
6. A co-founding team that does not respect the other founders skill set. They die.
5. A founder without the self-confidence needed to make the difficult decisions. They die.
4. A founder who is not prepared to fire team members who are not committed to the vision of the company, they die.
3. A founder that can't identify the difference between a hard and easy decision, treats every decision like it's their last, and they die from indecision.
2. A founder who takes everyone advice, never makes progress, because they build a camel (a camel was a horse designed by a committee). So they die.
1. A founder who hedges never makes progress. They always want to have a plan B, and startups can't have a plan B. They run out of money and die.

I have now invested in 330 companies personally or through @BoostVC. I'm not going to claim to be the perfect answer to what makes the perfect recipe for success, but I can tell you the perfect recipe for death.
Why do startups die?

17/ But who knows... it's all just luck right.

16/ I think we are about to see the rise of quantification of venture capital. High frequency capital is about to start happening. Data collection, quantifiable networks, and verticalization of strengths.
15/ I think we will continue to see a democratization of global access. Remote Work is going to be a trend that we will continue to see.

14/ The gap between money and the idea is narrowing, and that will continue to shrink. The value of capital will become minimal to a startup. The value of networks will continue to compound, so digital identity will become exceptionally valuable.

13/ At the core, Venture Capital is a service business. We are translators between maniacs and conservatives. We connect ideas to capital, and the past to the future. We are a network, that serves the company... the VCs who forget the service part of the business will lose.
12/ This leads to the question of what is next? What does a VC look like in the next 10 years?

11/ To give a prompt, @BoostVC forked the @ycombinator model 7 years ago and identified that there was an underserved network building in #SciFiTech... It's working... building in blindspots is fun. We have become something else.
10/ and the network just keeps compounding.

9/ But big funds can't do what @ycombinator does. Their business model doesn't fit the mold, and there are features that YC did from the beginning in their DNA that can't be replicated retroactively. (deal standards, volume of deals, programmatic investing, scale)

8/ Asymmetrical access means own the relationship the earliest or control a brand that can win the deal. These are the only two defensible pieces in Venture Capital today. This has lead every venture fund to attempt a model that replicates what YC does.

7/ Enter @ycombinator, the most disruptive model in venture capital. I think most VCs don't even recognize their power. They identified the core change in venture capital. Venture Capital was no longer about asymmetrical information, it was about asymmetrical access.
6/ Standards of deals, standards for every startup, which lead to a much more efficient market.

5/ I think there were tangential changes that no one could have predicted: any person could be a media empire, information on the internet continues to deliver compounding value, and the cost of starting a company was literally code. It also created the ability for standards.

4/ The organization/ubiquity and low cost of communication and IT brought the cost of starting a company to virtually zero. Venture Capital kept doing things the old way... but a few people identified this change... any developer could start a company.

3/ Ironically, Venture Capitalists funded the companies that allowed for the rapid evolution and micro-disruption of their business. The internet companies: @Google , @facebook , @Skype , @amazon , @Twitter...

2/ Venture Capital used to be about proprietary deal flow. Where you would have asymmetric information that no one else held, and use it to your advantage. In the world of capital consolidation, this worked really well.
1/ I was at @ycombinator demo day today, and it made me start thinking about how the internet changed Venture Capital:

9/ If you know someone in the Ocean world, please contact me. If you are a founder there, please connect to me. I'm obsessed, and want to profitably help the planet.
8/ The Ocean is the oldest frontier, and it's time to solve global problems with the latest technology.

7/ I believe that this new industry plays well to our strengths @BoostVC, where we build networks in emerging tech and unite founders working on hard problems from all over the world. We have built these communities in #Crypto and #VR as proof points.
6/ Theres a trash heap the size of Texas we should clean up and 50% of Coral Reefs will be dead by 2050. I think we need for profit startups to take a crack at solving these issues.
5/ We hope to flip the business model of the ocean, by investing in For-Profit #OceanTech startups. Showing that aligning incentives is a great way to make change.
4/ This knowledge has led @BoostVC to focus on finding entrepreneurs solving the hardest problems in the Ocean. We believe that the ocean is the answer. #OceanTech
3/ The Ocean is the answer to some of the largest problems plaguing humanity today: Climate Change, Food Shortage, Energy and Water.
2/ Because no country owns the ocean, no one takes pride or ownership in it, and thus we find ourselves with a tragedy of the commons problem... literally a trash heap.
1/ The Ocean needs a new business model and @BoostVC wants to give it one by investing in #OceanTech founders. üåäüåäüåäüåé

I do the deals that I think best will:
- Connect the worlds financial infrastructure
- Decentralize governance
- Surprise the world

Not doing accredited investor exclusive deals hurts the entrepreneur in the US, not the investor.

Full thought: 
In a world where every deal is shared, and every startup is your investment competition, how do you win? 

Together is how we win :) Remember it's not #Crypto against Crypto, it's crypto against complacency and centralization. It's about connecting the world.
2C/\n#Crypto has broken Venture Capital habits that have been around for 50 years.
2B/ \nSuddenly the competition is not only other venture funds, it's also tokens who have raised capital or major #Crypto unicorns.
2A/ \n@BoostVC lost 2 deals recently to our own Portfolio companies who are trying to buy up as much talent as they can.
2/ \nDeals are being acquired before they complete their fundraise.
1F/\nAnother thought is that you have to Tribe up, because otherwise you have to compete with the open market, which makes the market incredibly entrepreneur friendly. (obviously a great thing)
1D/\nThere is an argument to be made that it takes a village of networks to win, when dealing with decentralized products.
1C/\nIt could also be a lack of confidence in the industry by the investors. I feel that leading used to be about showing strength, and now it's a shared task.
1B/\nMaybe it is a way to diversify risk for investors.
1A/ \nEvery deal is invested in by @A16Z, @Polychain, @naval , @PanteraCapital , @DCGco... X Y and Z. Never just one of them. (@BoostVC is in there too)

6/ #VR is one of the most important tech revolutions in the history of time, because it's about time that technology connected us to each other, rather than just connecting us to information.

5/ VR is infinite. VR is unlocking geography in a way that has never been possible. As humans we will feel more connected than ever before. We are now able to live in a digital world that had only previously been visited through a window (Computer/phone)

4/ The biggest competition to #VR is @united airlines. Trillions of dollars a year is spent on Business travel, #VR will reduce this to Billions in the next decade. Presence and collaboration can be achieved with a simple device.

3/ Online Learning will no longer be a subset of learning, or a derivative form of taking classes, it will be the most impactful way to be educated by the best globally. Access to knowledge is democratized.
2/ Online Fitness will have a whole new meaning when you can work out with full classes in #VR, the startups use your own real estate in your home rather than retail space.
1/ The killer app of #VR is social collaboration, but this unlocks incredible potential for businesses and consumers globally.\n\nThe #VR virus is spreading. It is unstoppable.
